contentrichtext.text: '''Quinquina''' is a variety of [[Apéritif and digestif | apéritif wines]]. Traditionally quinquinas contain [[cinchona]] bark, which provides [[quinine]]. Quinine was used in treating malaria. <ref name="vermouth101">[http://vermouth101.com/index.html Vermouth 101]</ref> '''Americano''' is considered either a subclass of quinquina, or a separate variety of apéritif. The root ''amer'' means bitter. Americano uses [[Gentiana|gentian root]] as the primary ingredient for flavoring and bitterness. <ref name="vermouth101-quinquina">[http://vermouth101.com/quinquinas.html Quinquina & Americano by Brand]</ref> Quinquina also refers to [[Peruvian Bark]], which originates from South America. It was introduced to Europe in the 17th century by Spanish missionaries. Some quinquinas are:<ref name="vermouth101-quinquina"/> * Bonal Gentiane Quina * [[Byrrh]] * [[Cocchi Americano]] * [[Contratto]] Americano Rosso * [[Dubonnet]] * [[Lillet]] Blanc * MAiDENii * St. Raphaël ==References== {{commons category}} <references/> {{Reflist}} [[Category:Bitters]] {{drink-stub}}
